bibl.explicit: Closing Words of Text (exclusive of any rubric or colophon which might follow it).
bibl.author: Ibn al-ʿArabī
bibl.date: Terminus post quem and terminus ante quem

noteGrp.note: A bibliography written by IA in which he lists 260 (+) of his works and 70 of his teachers. It was written for a sultan, variously known as al-Muẓaffar or al-Muʿaẓẓam Bahāʾ al-Dīn or Shihāb al-Dīn Ghāzī b. al-Malik al-ʿĀdil, in 632H in Damascus.

bibl.note: OY cites 16 mss, although none can be considered historic. There are several ‘families’: one is represented by Koprulu 766 (dated by TRF as 632H but we have not been able to find evidence for this); another by Princeton Garrett 4098 (dated 949H) and Zahiriyya 4679 (dated 1305); and the third by Badawi’s edition (and other printed editions). There is also a hybrid, Shehit Ali 2796 (undated), connected to the library of M. b. Qayṣar who was the head of SQ’s zāwiya. The principal factor in verifying this text as by IA is textual, i.e. its correspondence with Fihris muʿallafāt (RG142) and the corpus of known IA works.

Add Edition par S. 'Abd al-Fattâh, Le Caire, 1995, dans le volume qui contient le K. manzil al-manâzil al-fahwâniyya (RG 412), d'après des mss. très tardifs de Dâr al-kutub. S. 'Abd al-Fattâh compare ce texte à celui édité par 'Afîfî (Revue de la Faculté des Lettres de l'Université d'Alexandrie, VIII, 1964) en pensant qu'il s'agit de deux versions d'un même ouvrage alors que le texte édité par 'Afîfî est le Fihris (RG 142) et non l'Ijâza (qui a été édité par 'Abd al-Rahmân Badawî dans Al -Andalus, vol. XX, fasc.1, 1955).
